title: Kanye West defends support for Trump claiming it's 'mental slavery' to base political views on race
text:
Hip-Hop star Kanye West defended his support for the Trump administration during his Sunday Service event in Utah over the weekend, insisting it would be ‘mental slavery’ to make political decisions based on race.

The outspoken rapper, 42, made the declaration in front of a 10,000-strong crowd at the the 189th Semiannual General Conference of The Church of Jesus Christ, in Salt Lake City on Saturday afternoon, having just finished performing his hit song ‘Jesus Walks’.

West’s lengthy monologue first began as a testimony about his journey to religious enlightenment, however, things quickly turned political when he told those gathered that it was the Republican Party - led by Abraham Lincoln - who emancipated slaves.

‘That’s the Republican Party that freed the slaves,’ West hailed in defense to those who slammed him for coming out as Trump supporter last year, adding that his political allegiances are his ‘right’.

‘And we got the right, right?’ We got a right to our opinions, right?’ West rhetorically asked. ‘They try to tell me because of my color who I'm supposed to pick as the president.’

The 21-time Grammy award winner then went onto suggest that allowing decisions to be based or influenced by skin color is a ‘form of slavery’.

‘You black, so you can't like Trump? I ain't never made a decision only based on my color,’ West said. ‘That's a form of slavery - mental slavery.’

West made similar remarks back in May during a a now infamous interview with TMZ where he provocatively stated that 400 years of slavery had been ‘a choice’.

‘When you hear about slavery for 400 years ... for 400 years? That sounds like a choice,’ he said at the time. ‘Like, you was there for 400 years and it’s all of y’all? It’s like we’re mentally in prison. I like the word “prison” because slavery goes too direct to the idea of blacks.

‘It’s like slavery, Holocaust. Holocaust, Jews, Slavery is blacks,' he added. 'So, prison is something that unites us as one race. Blacks and whites being one race. We’re the human race.’

It's thought that 10,000 people were in attendance during Kanye's performance on Saturday

His latest comments come just over a year after he made headlines delivering an impassioned speech in support of Trump during a controversial appearance on the Season 44 premiere of Saturday Night Live.

Just two weeks later, West visited the White House and delivered a convoluted 10-minute soliloquy directed at Trump, in which he likened his red ‘Make America Great Again’ cap to a ‘Superman cape’, and pitched an idea to replace Air Force One with an aircraft called the ‘iPlane 1.’

During Saturday’s speech, politics and religion weren’t the only topics on West’s mind.

He also hit out against ‘mind controllers’ in the media, and went on to decry the mass incarceration of African-Americans, voicing fearsome support for Criminal Justice Reform - a cause his wife Kim Kardashian is actively pursuing in collaboration with the Trump administration.

West, who hasn’t tweeted since the turn of the year, also spoke out in contempt of social media, warning his fans ‘not to read comments on the internet.’

‘These people don’t know you like that,’ he said. ‘Social media is designed to make you think slower ... They want to slow you down and control you.’
